document: This lecture covers basic algorithm concepts, induction proof techniques, and asymptotic notation.

questions.question: Every correct algorithm must terminate after a finite number of steps.
Induction can only be applied when the base case is n = 1.
An algorithm that runs in O(n) time always requires linear memory as well.
The definition of an algorithm includes a precise specification for every step.
A recursive algorithm is the same as an iterative one in terms of implementation.
Asymptotic notation describes how an algorithm behaves when the input size grows very large.
The big-O upper bound ignores constant factors.
In a weak induction proof, one assumes the statement holds for all values up to n-1.
Strong induction can start with two base cases: S(0) and S(1).
An algorithm that is correct for some inputs but not all is considered a valid algorithm.
The term 'space complexity' refers to the amount of memory used by an algorithm.
A linearithmic time algorithm has running time O(n log n).
The example 1 + 2 + ... + n = n(n+1)/2 is proved using induction.
A polynomial time algorithm can have running time O(2^n).
The base case for an inductive proof must always be the same as the hypothesis step.
In asymptotic analysis, we usually model a computer with a RAM machine where every memory access costs one unit of time.
A binary search algorithm runs in O(log n) time.
The term 'exponential time' refers to running times like O(2^n).
An algorithm that uses dynamic programming always runs faster than a bruteâ€‘force approach.
